### Recent News

The Rockets are returning from All-Star break and currently sit at No. 4 in the Western Conference, one full game back from Denver.[3] Kevin Durant has performed as an offensive superstar, averaging 24.7 points per game, while Alperen Sengun contributes 17.1 points and 9.1 rebounds.[1]

The Hornets have been one of the hottest teams in the league, winning nine consecutive games prior to the All-Star break and climbing to the ninth seed in the Eastern Conference with a 26-29 record.[3] LaMelo Ball (18.6 PPG, 6.4 APG), Brandon Miller (20.5 PPG), and rookie Kon Knueppel (18 PPG) form a potent offensive trio.[1] The Hornets recently defeated Atlanta 110-107 on February 11.[4]

The Hornets will be notably impacted by suspensions to Miles Bridges and Moussa Diabate stemming from a bench-clearing brawl with the Pistons.[3]

### Player & Team News
# Player-Focused News Report: Rockets @ Hornets

## Player Form & Streaks

**Charlotte's Momentum:** The Hornets are riding a **W1 streak** and have gone **9-1 over their last 10 games**, showing significant improvement after a rocky start to the season.[6] LaMelo Ball will be crucial to maintaining this form, though he's dealing with off-court distractions after a car crash during the All-Star break.[1]

**Houston's Recent Struggles:** The Rockets enter on an **L1 streak** despite holding a strong **6-4 record over their last 10 games**.[6] Kevin Durant (25.8 PPG) remains their primary offensive engine, but the team is navigating potential locker room tension following allegations about burner account activity on social media.[1]

## Rotation & Role Changes

Brandon Miller is expected to see increased minutes in this matchup after dealing with early foul trouble in the previous meeting between these teams.[1] The Hornets' offense will lean more heavily on Miller, LaMelo Ball, and Kon Knueppel to compensate for the absence of Miles Bridges.

## Returning Players & Ramp-Ups

Dorian Finney-Smith (knee) has been cleared from the injury report and is available for Houston's game against Charlotte.[5]

## Matchup Storylines

**Moussa Diabate as a Defensive Anchor:** Though suspended for this game, the search results highlight that Diabate creates significant matchup problems for Houston's Alperen Sengun due to his defensive versatility against slower-footed centers. His absence will allow Sengun more comfortable matchups against Ryan Kalkbrenner, Grant Williams, and PJ Hall.[1]

**Durant's Dominance in Previous Meeting:** In the Hornets' 109-99 victory over Houston earlier this season, Kevin Durant was the only Rocket to truly get going with 31 points, while Jabari Smith added 17. Alperen Sengun and Amen Thompson contributed minimally.[1] The Hornets will need to replicate that defensive approach, though without Bridges' impact, the task becomes more difficult.

**Offensive Firepower Mismatch:** Houston's depth—particularly with Durant, Sengun, and Smith—contrasts with Charlotte's more guard-oriented attack centered on Ball and Knueppel. The Hornets' previous success came partly from limiting role player contributions; repeating that will be essential.[1]
